Now, if $x$ belongs to ${D}_{1}$ and $y$ belongs to ${D}_{2}$, we no longer can define the function that way, because the domain is actually a set of heterogeneous tuples. In functional programming languages, such as Haskell, one can define such a function as either $f: ({D}_{1}, {D}_{2}) \rightarrow C$ or a curried function $f: {D}_{1} \rightarrow {D}_{2} \rightarrow C$.
